headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and CEO; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Fin
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and CEO; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Financial Officer. Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. 
I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions you may have. Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments and the use of non-GAAP financial measures. 
Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from expectations. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our SEC filings. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules maybe discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release, which is available on our website at www.autonation.com. 
And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mike Jackson

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today we reported record adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.45 for the fourth quarter, a 55% increase on a per-share basis as compared to $0.29 for the same period in the prior year. Fourth quarter 2010 r
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today we reported record adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.45 for the fourth quarter, a 55% increase on a per-share basis as compared to $0.29 for the same period in the prior year. Fourth quarter 2010 revenue totaled $3.2 billion compared to $2.8 billion in the year ago period, an increase of 16%, driven primarily by stronger new vehicle revenue. In the fourth quarter, total U.S. industry new vehicle retail sales increased 6% based on CNW Research Data. 
In comparison, during the same period, AutoNation's new vehicle unit sales increased 15% or 12% on a same-store basis. 
For the full year, adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $1.56 was a record, up 36% over prior year. Revenue for the full year was up 17% over prior year. This morning, we reported our January new vehicle retail sales which increased 24% continuing to demonstrate that the auto industry recovery is solidly underway. The January seasonally adjusted annual rate was $12,600,000, which was the highest since Lehman Brothers bankruptcy in September of '08 excluding Cash for Clunkers. 
We continue to see strength in Domestic sales which were up 40%. Imports increased 23% and Premium Luxury was up 5%. During the downturn, our aggressive cost reduction in Asset Management strategies resulted in a lower cost structure and more efficient inventory management. We continue to invest in our stores and in our share service center, where we centralized our store level accounting and administrative activities. We also selectively added to our portfolio by acquiring several new stores, including our announcement today that we've entered into an agreement to acquire one of the country's largest Toyota store Ft. Myers to Florida on the West Coast of Florida. 
AutoNation has an optimal brand and market mix that positions us for strong performance in new vehicle sales as the market rebounds. We have been consistently demonstrating our ability to perform in what we expect to be a multiyear recovery in auto retail. Thank you very much. 
Turning it over to Mr. Short.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the fourth quarter, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $68 million or $0.45 per share versus $50 million or $0.29 per share during the fourth quarter of 2009, a 55% impro
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the fourth quarter, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $68 million or $0.45 per share versus $50 million or $0.29 per share during the fourth quarter of 2009, a 55% improvement on a per-share basis. 
During the third quarter of 2010 conference call, we mentioned that we expected to earn approximately $20 million in performance-based manufacturer incentives over the next two to three quarters, primarily related to Premium Luxury vehicles previous sold. 
In Q4, operating income was favorably impacted by approximately $11.8 million due to the recognition of these incentives. We expect to recognize an additional favorable impact of approximately $9 million in operating income related to these incentives over the next two quarters. 
Our fourth quarter 2009 results excluding the favorable tax adjustment of $12.7 million or $0.07 per share and there were no adjusting items in the fourth quarter of 2010. For the full year, our adjusted EPS was $1.56 compared to $1.15 in the prior year. The adjustments to net income are included in the reconciliations provided in our press release. 
Fourth quarter revenue increased $452.2 million or 16% compared to the prior year. Gross profit improved $71.4 million or 15%, while SG&A was up $32.5 million or 9% for the quarter. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 72.1% for the quarter. This benefited from an improved gross profit due to the manufacturer incentives previously mentioned. Excluding that impact, SG&A's percentage of gross profit would have been in line with third quarter of 2010 and approximately 240 basis points lower than Q4 of prior year. 
Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $2.8 million for the quarter, a decrease of $1.5 million from the $4.3 million benefit in the fourth quarter of last year due primarily to higher average floorplan balances during the quarter. 
Non-vehicle interest expense was $16.3 million for the quarter, up from the $10.2 million we reported in the fourth quarter of 2009 due to our refinancing which closed in April 2010. Our percentage of fixed rate debt was 33% prior to insurance compared to 47% at the end of the fourth quarter. Refinancing also increased the pricing under our revolver and term loan facilities from LIBOR plus 87.5 basis points to LIBOR plus 225 basis points. 
During the quarter, we paid down $30 million under our revolving credit facility resulting in $180 million of outstanding borrowings on our revolver at the end of the fourth quarter. Our fourth quarter non-vehicle debt balance was $1.349 billion, an increase of $236 million compared to the fourth quarter of 2009 but a decrease of $32 million compared with the third quarter of 2010. 
LIBOR rates were relatively flat compared with the fourth quarter of 2009. The provision for income tax in the quarter was $41 million or 37.7%. This reflects the benefit of certain favorable tax adjustments. 
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased approximately 731,000 shares or $17 million at an average price of $23.38. For the full year, we repurchased 26.6 million shares for $524 million at an average price of $19.70. We ended the fourth quarter with 148.4 million shares outstanding and $233 million of Board authorization remaining for future share repurchases. 
Capital expenditures for the quarter excluding operating lease buyouts was $72.7 million, resulting in full year 2010 capital expenditures of $150 million net of operating lease buyouts as we continue to invest in our facilities. For 2011, we expect CapEx to be approximately $140 million excluding proceeds from remaining asset sales. 
Floorplan debt was approximately $1.9 billion at quarter end, up approximately $233 million from September 30, 2010 and in line with inventory levels. Our balance sheet continues to be industry-leading and we remained well within the limits of our financial covenants. 
Our leverage ratio was 2.41x at the end of the quarter compared to the limit of 3.25x. Our quarter end cash balance was $95 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in healthy total liquidity of over $550 million at the end of December. 
Our cash flow generation, combined with our strong balance sheet and streamlined cost structure, positioned the company to continue to benefit from the improving SAR and to maximize the value of the company and shareholder returns. 
Let me now turn you over to our President and Chief Operating Officer, Mike Maroone.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Our entire team is committed to outperforming the market as the economy recovers. And in 2010, we did just that. We are very proud of our strong operating results for both the fourth quarter and the full year 2010
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. Our entire team is committed to outperforming the market as the economy recovers. And in 2010, we did just that. We are very proud of our strong operating results for both the fourth quarter and the full year 2010 that netted an impressive 4.1% operating margin for the quarter and an industry-leading 4% operating margin for the full year. Our performance was achieved with elite levels of CSI, increased associate productivity and the lowest associate turnover in the company's history. 
In the quarter, we grew new vehicle unit volume 15% on a total store basis and 12% for same stores comparing favorably to the industry, which according to CNW, was up 6%. Performance was also impressive for used vehicles where in the quarter we achieved growth of 21% for total stores and 19% for same stores. Contributing to the lift in volume was strong performances in our three largest states of California, Texas and Florida, where our brand mix, locations and operating teams execution were a clear benefit. 
Looking at segment performance. At $122 million total segment income for the fourth quarter grew 42% or $36 million compared to the period a year ago. Segment income for the Domestic segment increased $13 million or 55% to $37 million. Premium Luxury increased $17 million or 36% to $66 million and Import segment income increased $5 million or 11% to $46 million. For the full year 2010, total segment income of $454 million was up $82 million or 22% compared to 2009 with year-over-year growth in all three segments.  As I continue my comments will be on a same-store basis unless noted otherwise. 
In the fourth quarter, AutoNation retailed 52,000 new vehicles, an increase of 5,500 units or 12% compared to the period a year ago. The Domestic segment accounted for just over half of the unit increase driven primarily by Ford where new units sold increased 30%. The Import segment accounted for about 40% of the new unit increase and Premium Luxury accounted for the balance of the increase in volume. 
Gross profit for new vehicle retail increased $129 or 6% to $2,416 per vehicle compared to the period a year ago. Gross profit as a percent of revenue increased 30 basis points to 7.2%. 
Excluding the special performance-based manufacturer incentives, in the quarter, gross profit per new vehicle retail was $2,163 of $124 or 5%. And gross profit as a percent of revenue was up 50 basis points to 6.4%. We attribute this primarily to year-over-year margin compression in the Import segment due in part to increased inventory compared to the post-Cash for Clunkers period a year ago where Import inventory depleted. 
Sequentially, from Q3 to Q4, again excluding the special performance-based manufacturer incentives, we were pleased to increase PBR by $168 or 8% with all three segments contributing to the growth. At December 31, our new vehicle day supply was 63 days comparing favorably to the industry at 68 days. And with 48,500 units, our year-end inventory represented what we consider a more normalized level. 
Turning to used vehicles. We delivered a strong 19% growth in used units retail for both the quarter and the full year. Focusing on Q4, retail used vehicle revenue was up 22% on the sale of 38,000 used vehicles with revenue per vehicle up 2% to 17,500. 
Gross profit per vehicle retail of $1,572 increased $80 or 5% with gross profit as a percent of revenue increasing 20 basis points compared to the period a year ago. Our used-to-new ratio in the quarter was 0.74, up from 0.70 a year ago. And at December 31, our used vehicle day supply was 42 days. 
I'd like to provide a quick update on our Value Vehicle Outlets or VVOs, where to address industry supply constraints and meet market demand, we are retailing value-priced vehicles that we would've traditionally wholesaled. In the fourth quarter, VVO sales accounted for 6% of our used vehicle volume and an average selling price of $7,800. Today, we have 19 VVO locations in operation with five more scheduled to open in the third quarter. 
Our Parts, Service and Collision business drove growth both in revenue and gross profit in the quarter. Revenue of $546 million represented an increase of $32 million or 6% with customer pay revenue, warranty and internal all contributing factors. We were very pleased to recognize a 4% increase in customer pay revenue compared to the period a year ago, our strongest performance in three years, as well as an 8% increase in warranty and a 19% increase in internal. 
Service, Parts and Collision Q4 gross profit of $236 million increased $11 million or 5% compared to a year ago, driven by an 11% increase in warranty related to large-scale recalls that were announced earlier in the year and a 13% increase in internal. 
Our FNI team turned in strong results with FNI gross profit per vehicle retail of $1,164, an increase of $36 or 3% compared to a year ago. Our preferred lender network OEM service contract alliances, strong product penetration and strong store-level execution continue to drive our performance in FNI. 
In the quarter, we relocated Mercedes-Benz of Miami, Mercedes-Benz of Southbay in Southern California and BMW Mini of Dallas to brand-new, large facilities. We also opened Peoria, a flagship Audi store in Addpoint in Peoria, Arizona. At December 31, our store portfolio was 206 stores and 242 franchises in 15 states. 
To reconcile the account at the end of Q3 during the fourth quarter, we divested one store with three franchises and terminated seven Pontiac franchises. These actions represented a combined annual revenue run rate of $77 million. And as you now know, we have an agreement to acquire Ft. Myers Toyota on the West Coast of Florida, the 35th largest Toyota store in the nation in 2010, ranked by new vehicle unit sales. We expect this transaction to be completed by the end of the first quarter and look forward to welcoming the store to AutoNation and our Florida region. 
I'd like to note that we have 16 major facility projects slated for completion this year. Six are new stores needed for digital points awarded to us by manufacturers and the remaining 10 will significantly upgrade existing stores or de-greenfield sites. 
Looking ahead, we continue to seek acquisition opportunities that meet our market brand and return on investment criteria. 
In closing, we are very proud of our performance in 2010 and thank each of our 19,000 associates for their contributions. Our formula for success remains continuous improvement of our best practice processes, intense focus on retaining our low-cost base and investing and training and developing our people. We believe these efforts and our store portfolio position us well to take advantage of the improving market. 
With that, I'll turn the call back to Mike Jackson

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. As we look in 2011, we believe that the gradual improvement in new vehicle sales will continue. Our planning assumption for 2011, industry new vehicle unit sales is 12,800,000 units and a retail selling rate of 10,200,000, both of which woul
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. As we look in 2011, we believe that the gradual improvement in new vehicle sales will continue. Our planning assumption for 2011, industry new vehicle unit sales is 12,800,000 units and a retail selling rate of 10,200,000, both of which would represent 11% improvement over 2010. 
With that, I'll be happy to take any questions.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is coming from Patrick Archambault, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is coming from Patrick Archambault, Goldman Sachs.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Could you give us an overview of how the competitive environment is playing out in new -- your grosses there came in I guess ahead of our expectation even -- and I guess part of that -- well I don't know, actually, maybe the incentives were probably in SG
componenttext: Could you give us an overview of how the competitive environment is playing out in new -- your grosses there came in I guess ahead of our expectation even -- and I guess part of that -- well I don't know, actually, maybe the incentives were probably in SG&A books. So they might not have impacted the grosses but they seem to be pretty strong there nonetheless. And I know that in the past, you talked about trying to take share in that environment which have compacted margins a little bit and it seems like a number of other large dealers were following suit. How has that changed since last quarter? Has the behavior there become a little bit less aggressive on the discounting side?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Jackson. If you look at our sales results, we definitely, in our big states, California, Texas and Florida, where for the industry the retail increase was in low-single digits. We had double-digit increases. So we an excellent performance from o
componenttext: It's Mike Jackson. If you look at our sales results, we definitely, in our big states, California, Texas and Florida, where for the industry the retail increase was in low-single digits. We had double-digit increases. So we an excellent performance from our stores. On the volume side which we are very satisfied with. We told you in the third quarter that we would make an effort on the front-end margin.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you exclude the special performance-based incentives, we increased our PVRs by $175 and it was a focus throughout the company. We really thought there was more opportunity in new vehicle margins. And frankly, we see the margin stabilizing going forward
componenttext: If you exclude the special performance-based incentives, we increased our PVRs by $175 and it was a focus throughout the company. We really thought there was more opportunity in new vehicle margins. And frankly, we see the margin stabilizing going forward. So I think Q3 was a little bit of an aberration but we drove the improvement in Q4. And I think going forward, we'll see stability in margins.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I wanted to focus on parts and service. That was I think another area where you did better than I think a lot of expectations with that growth rate. Could you maybe just give us a little bit of a overview of how you expect those three subsegments to t
componenttext: And I wanted to focus on parts and service. That was I think another area where you did better than I think a lot of expectations with that growth rate. Could you maybe just give us a little bit of a overview of how you expect those three subsegments to trend on a go-forward basis in 2011?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Patrick, again, it's Mike Maroone. We have put a lot of time, effort and resources behind the customer pay and really feel that, that's the key. That's the one that's most in our control. So we have positive growth in the quarter. It's our best performanc
componenttext: Patrick, again, it's Mike Maroone. We have put a lot of time, effort and resources behind the customer pay and really feel that, that's the key. That's the one that's most in our control. So we have positive growth in the quarter. It's our best performance in three years. And I think going forward, I think we can expect to see somewhere between 3% and 5% revenue growth in customer pay. Internal, as you know, clearly moves with volume. And in an improving market. I think you'll see continue to strengthen there, hopefully, a double-digit strength. And the warranty is a little bit of a wild card because there was a fair amount of recalls especially on the Toyota-Lexus side that were certainly an influence in warranty but we're not seeing in that double digit decline in warranty that we've seen in the past. So again, I don't know that we can make predictions on what the recall environment is going to be like so our efforts are really focused on customer pay.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. On recall for the industry, it was $20 million last year which is the third highest ever. The peak is $30 million recall. Second highest is $25 million. So considerable level of recalls. I don't have any idea whether that level would
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. On recall for the industry, it was $20 million last year which is the third highest ever. The peak is $30 million recall. Second highest is $25 million. So considerable level of recalls. I don't have any idea whether that level would repeat this year or not and overall quality still gets better.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to your earlier question because it sounds like you had a question where the incentives are booked. The special incentives that we are seeing from the manufacturers, the $20 million that we called out last quarter, the benefit of th
componenttext: I just want to go back to your earlier question because it sounds like you had a question where the incentives are booked. The special incentives that we are seeing from the manufacturers, the $20 million that we called out last quarter, the benefit of that is booked in gross profit. There is, when you do the ratio obviously because gross profit goes up and there's not much expense associated with those incentive dollars, you do see a corresponding lift or improvement in the SG&A as a percentage of growth.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Rick Nelson of Stephens.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Rick Nelson of Stephens.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The industry sold 3 million actual units in the fourth quarter. AutoNation made $0.45 in the fourth quarter. If we annualize both those numbers, it implies $1.80 and a 12 million unit environment. Is that the right way to look at earnings power? Or do we
componenttext: The industry sold 3 million actual units in the fourth quarter. AutoNation made $0.45 in the fourth quarter. If we annualize both those numbers, it implies $1.80 and a 12 million unit environment. Is that the right way to look at earnings power? Or do we need to make adjustments for these incentives that came in fourth quarter?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we've been very clear that the fourth quarter include $0.05 of special additional incentive, of which there is still another $0.03 to $0.04 to come in the first and second quarter. And then after that, there will be a normalized run rate on front
componenttext: I think we've been very clear that the fourth quarter include $0.05 of special additional incentive, of which there is still another $0.03 to $0.04 to come in the first and second quarter. And then after that, there will be a normalized run rate on front end gross along the line of what Mr. Maroone called out.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The OEMs are talking about higher commodity and other costs. If they raise prices higher costs, how do you see that playing out for the deal then?
componenttext: The OEMs are talking about higher commodity and other costs. If they raise prices higher costs, how do you see that playing out for the deal then?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I don't see it as a serious issue. The consumers demonstrated a willingness to pay for more content. So and we don't hear anything from the manufacturers about significant precipitous price increases. To me, if I look at the year, the wildcard is gasoline
componenttext: I don't see it as a serious issue. The consumers demonstrated a willingness to pay for more content. So and we don't hear anything from the manufacturers about significant precipitous price increases. To me, if I look at the year, the wildcard is gasoline prices. If we have a spike in gasoline prices up above $4 a gallon, where I think the industries is prepared, this year to handle than we're in '08, it's still something that is disruptive for a couple of months. But I think inventory is so much lower and every manufacturer has fuel-efficient vehicles and I think the free GAAP point for the customer was higher than it was in '08. I think we're better to able to handle it. But I think to me that the wildcard of the year and not pricing.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Also For used car comps have been terrific first time even I guess anniversary-ing some really tough comps a year ago. When do you see that customer switching from used to new? And I guess how sustainable do you think that used car growth is?
componenttext: Also For used car comps have been terrific first time even I guess anniversary-ing some really tough comps a year ago. When do you see that customer switching from used to new? And I guess how sustainable do you think that used car growth is?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. I think that there is a portion of the customer base that moves from certified pre-owned to new. Today, certified preowned is about 30% of our mix but there's a strong demand on the used vehicle side. We haven't seen that fall off at al
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. I think that there is a portion of the customer base that moves from certified pre-owned to new. Today, certified preowned is about 30% of our mix but there's a strong demand on the used vehicle side. We haven't seen that fall off at all. The real issue in use is supply and we're working were really hard on supply side. We're very optimistic that we can continue to grow the used at least in line with the new maybe more. And I'm very pleased with the value vehicle outlet that's performing I think at a high level in this incremental business for the company. So I think there's still more opportunity in used and we got a great used car team that's working very hard at it.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Short. I just wanted to follow-up on your question on EPS. I think quoting me as I really believe that nothing happens until you sell a quarter, right? But I think you may feel a little bit oversimplistic to say that you can look at the SAR n
componenttext: This is Mike Short. I just wanted to follow-up on your question on EPS. I think quoting me as I really believe that nothing happens until you sell a quarter, right? But I think you may feel a little bit oversimplistic to say that you can look at the SAR number, extrapolate it out to what that necessarily means for EPS. Remember that our fixed operations gross profit represents half of the overall gross profit stream for the organization. So I would just probably -- I think you can get some rough ideas generally about that but I would temper it with obviously, the level of modeling that you typically do in a lot more detail.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Matt Ziemer, Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Matt Ziemer, Wells Fargo.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: My first question is I guess more of a housekeeping question but can you just remind us what's different about this luxury incentive program versus the typical stair-step program? And should we expect that we might see more of these going forward? Or do y
componenttext: My first question is I guess more of a housekeeping question but can you just remind us what's different about this luxury incentive program versus the typical stair-step program? And should we expect that we might see more of these going forward? Or do you think this is truly a one-time or trying to figure out whether we should take this out of the bottle or not?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Because it's a multiyear commitment over a very period of time that has many performance hoops on it before you would earn the money. And you didn't know for sure until you dotted every i and crossed every t's and indeed, you would get it. Therefore, it i
componenttext: Because it's a multiyear commitment over a very period of time that has many performance hoops on it before you would earn the money. And you didn't know for sure until you dotted every i and crossed every t's and indeed, you would get it. Therefore, it is going to be recognize even though over extended period of time. And there are no manufacturer programs in place that mirror these programs at the moment that I would sit here and say, "Well, if I look at 2012, this is going to occur again." And that sense, I cant say we got another one of these things in progress. So these programs are coming to the completion and they have not been reformulated by the manufacturers.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So typically, a stair-step program would even though you may not know that you're going to hit your target until the following quarter, you do accrue for that?
componenttext: So typically, a stair-step program would even though you may not know that you're going to hit your target until the following quarter, you do accrue for that?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is not stairstep. So other performance metrics, long list, no reason to take you through it. It's not stairstep but it is retro in the sense that you have to achieve all these performance targets and then you can receive the money that you have
componenttext: Yes, this is not stairstep. So other performance metrics, long list, no reason to take you through it. It's not stairstep but it is retro in the sense that you have to achieve all these performance targets and then you can receive the money that you have earned over an extended period of time.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then turning to the Used Vehicle business. Should we expect that as the outlets become more successful and as there are more of them out there, that your average price per vehicle sold will go down a little bit and your gross profit per vehicle sold w
componenttext: And then turning to the Used Vehicle business. Should we expect that as the outlets become more successful and as there are more of them out there, that your average price per vehicle sold will go down a little bit and your gross profit per vehicle sold will also see some pressure obviously, offset by higher units?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. I think that's correct. The average selling price of our VVO units is in the $7,500 range. It probably has an impact of about $50 diminishment in our gross margin. But again, we look at as all incremental. And on top of the gross margin
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. I think that's correct. The average selling price of our VVO units is in the $7,500 range. It probably has an impact of about $50 diminishment in our gross margin. But again, we look at as all incremental. And on top of the gross margin you see, there is reconditioning profits and there is finance profits so we think they're an important part of the business. I think it's going to be a growing part of the business and we'll see how far it goes. But so far, so good.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, I'm just wondering if you can comment on what you're seeing in terms of floor traffic that might be impacted or mix that might be impacted by higher crude, higher gas prices and the weather that we are seeing around the country?
componenttext: And then just lastly, I'm just wondering if you can comment on what you're seeing in terms of floor traffic that might be impacted or mix that might be impacted by higher crude, higher gas prices and the weather that we are seeing around the country?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nothing yet. No, if you look at January sales, no impact on truck vehicles whatsoever even though we've had a $0.50 increase in the price of gasoline over the net last 90 to 100 days, breaking through $3 a gallon. We've seen no change in consumer behavior
componenttext: Nothing yet. No, if you look at January sales, no impact on truck vehicles whatsoever even though we've had a $0.50 increase in the price of gasoline over the net last 90 to 100 days, breaking through $3 a gallon. We've seen no change in consumer behavior.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: On California, Florida and Texas, you mentioned that you outperformed those markets. Those are strong markets but you also outperformed the markets. And we are seeing pretty strong grosses coming from you across the board on new vehicles. I'm just trying
componenttext: On California, Florida and Texas, you mentioned that you outperformed those markets. Those are strong markets but you also outperformed the markets. And we are seeing pretty strong grosses coming from you across the board on new vehicles. I'm just trying to understand how you're gaining market share and improving gross margins at the same time? Are we just finally seeing the benefits of consolidation in the dealer base coming through? Or is this just a much stronger with the level demand that allows you to raise grosses? I'm sure you understand how those two factors are working in unison.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say first as an overarching statement and I've said this before but maybe now is significant as others is coming out. We are in a very defensive posture of '05, '06, '07, '08. I mean we really were concerned that there was more downside than upsid
componenttext: I would say first as an overarching statement and I've said this before but maybe now is significant as others is coming out. We are in a very defensive posture of '05, '06, '07, '08. I mean we really were concerned that there was more downside than upside. And in that sense, you have to manage everything assuming things are going to get worse. And then when they got worse, you have to assume they're going to get even worse. So that really changes how you approach the market. As soon as we saw that the worst was over that would have been June of '09, we switched from defense to offense where our risk profile changed on every categories from inventory levels to marketing to initiatives. And that combined with throughout that period, we always invested in our initiatives, around process and technology. But if you combine the power of those initiatives now with a lean-forward posture, you could see the payoff. So Mr. Maroone, what would you like to add?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I just think that we have got a great team out there, great stability and we really focused on execution. And I think Mike really said it, we continue to invest in people and technology in the downturn although we were conservative in certain parts of the
componenttext: I just think that we have got a great team out there, great stability and we really focused on execution. And I think Mike really said it, we continue to invest in people and technology in the downturn although we were conservative in certain parts of the business and I think we're now seeing the payoff.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't always get it right. If you look at the third quarter, we said we were unhappy with our front end gross and that we were going to address it. But the fourth quarter says is that when we give direction, we can achieve it at the store level. And we
componenttext: We don't always get it right. If you look at the third quarter, we said we were unhappy with our front end gross and that we were going to address it. But the fourth quarter says is that when we give direction, we can achieve it at the store level. And we'll make these constant refinement as we go forward and see where the opportunity is in the marketplace. But by and large, we think we're going to outperform in the marketplace.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, John. It's door number two. You've got it right. We don't see anything significant in the marketplace that's different than fourth quarter or even different from a year ago. It's a constant refinement process but there's no significant change in the l
componenttext: No, John. It's door number two. You've got it right. We don't see anything significant in the marketplace that's different than fourth quarter or even different from a year ago. It's a constant refinement process but there's no significant change in the level of incentives that we see at the store level. The only incentives that we think and we always believe that there will be incentives and tax incentives defined. The only incentive that we dislike intensely are stairstep programs which create a lot of chaos and mistrust in the marketplace and really don't have a place in today's Internet world, where basically with stairsteps you are telling the customer unless they're shot to death, they may not find where the stairstep is heading and that has no place in today's marketplace. But other than that, I think the manufacturer incentives are pretty much in line and it's more a repackaging and recommunication than anything that's really changed significantly.

componenttext: No, I really don't. I don't see GM  selling and going. I would describe GM improvements this way. GM launched some very exciting products in the last year and dramatically misjudged the demand-supply equation. So GM is trying not to over produce and they dramatically underproduce vis-Ã -vis the demand they created for the new products. Now the production is much more in line with demand and you are seeing that in their sales. And I view the incentives as tweaking nothing really that dramatic. Mr. Maroone, do you see any difference?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I see it the same way. I see it as tactical tweaks. And they have a lot of confidence that they understand that the old push system is dead and we don't have a lot of pressure to buy unwanted inventory. I think they've found the right balance and I don't
componenttext: I see it the same way. I see it as tactical tweaks. And they have a lot of confidence that they understand that the old push system is dead and we don't have a lot of pressure to buy unwanted inventory. I think they've found the right balance and I don't think incentives will be a bigger part of the industry.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean on a regular basis with Allen, Ackerson and Sergio, and this is the most remarkable thing I see at the top of these companies, there is a feeling of never again. These are smart shrewd businessmen that are in this to get return on their capital a
componenttext:
I mean on a regular basis with Allen, Ackerson and Sergio, and this is the most remarkable thing I see at the top of these companies, there is a feeling of never again. These are smart shrewd businessmen that are in this to get return on
 their capital and produce sustainable profits and they know they have to produce vehicles that people actually want to buy for that to happen. So I am a completely convinced that this is a new business model. And I assure you when we see behavior that this is not in alignment with that, we will speak out. And really, the last legacy of production for us is stairstep that has no place in this new world. It unleashes the worst behavior. It lose for the manufacturer, lose for the dealer, lose for the consumer. That's the last thing that has to be stamped out. And it's ironic, Detroit is not the practitioner of stairsteps. There's certain out there. So I think Detroit is it great shape

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: I think in terms of the overall cost structures, we did a lot of heavy lifting in the end of '07 and early '08 timeframe to take out the structural cost. We continue to invest in productivity-enhancing initiatives. Our shared service center being probably the best example of that. And we are going to continue to do that so over time, we look for continued operating leverage in the business. We have an SG&A as a percentage of gross profit below 70%. At one point, it moves fast and there's a goal for us it out there in the future.

componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. We are seeing strength across the country. On a full year basis, Texas, we are up about 13%. California we're up 10-ish. Florida, up 13%. Colorado, up 16. Still feeling some pressure in Arizona and Nevada but our key markets really have started to come back. componenttext: It's Mike Jackson. As an overview, the underpinnings of the results for last year were very much credit related, the healing of credit particularly in prime, end prime. Except for the level of down payment, they're just about normalized. We expect the underpinning of the recovery this year to be credit improvement in subprime and leasing as well as of those customers in near prime and prime having saved their down payment since they can't use home equity any more but all that is going to come along. And then, we'll need for 2012 and 2013 a stronger employment story and a stronger housing story. Both of which, I believe, will unfold this year. But that remains to be seen. Mr. Maroone, anything you want to add?
