headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's First Quarter 2011 Conference Call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Financi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's First Quarter 2011 Conference Call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Financial Officer. 
Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Kate Kaiser and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions you may have.
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments and the use of non-GAAP financial measures. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. 
Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from expectations. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our SEC filings. Certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC rules may be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release, which is available on our website at www.autonation.com. And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today we reported record adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.46 for the first quarter, a 35% increase on a per-share basis as compared to $0.34 for the same period in the prior year. Gross profit for all o
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today we reported record adjusted EPS from continuing operations of $0.46 for the first quarter, a 35% increase on a per-share basis as compared to $0.34 for the same period in the prior year. Gross profit for all of our major categories improved compared to the first quarter of 2010 and our expense structure remained very disciplined. 
First quarter 2011 revenue totaled $3.3 billion compared to $2.8 billion in the year-ago period, an increase of 17% driven primarily by stronger new vehicle revenue. In the first quarter, AutoNation's new vehicle unit sales increased 23% or 20% on a same-store basis, which were in line with the industry according to CNW Research Data. 
In March, we began to see a mixshift with consumers gradually moving to mid-size and small vehicles as gas prices increase, fuel efficiencies has written on the consumer consideration shopping list and is now in the top 10 according to CNW.
We are, of course, supportive of the efforts of our Japanese base partners as they worked hard to rebuild and begin production and bring it back online. To support the recovery efforts, AutoNation has made a donation of $100,000 to the American Red Cross. While the underlying recovery in consumer demand for autos remains on track in the United States due to Japanese supply constraints throughout the remainder of 2011, we are reducing our planning assumptions for the 2011 full year U.S. industry sales to mid-12 million new vehicle units. 
Based on current information, we see significant reductions in vehicle shipments from the Japanese manufacturers through year end with a resumption of normal shipment level in early 2012. I'll now turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer, Mike Short.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the first quarter we reported net income from continuing operations of $70.3 million or $0.46 per share versus $58.8 billion or $0.34 per share during the first quarter of 2010, a 35% improvement on
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the first quarter we reported net income from continuing operations of $70.3 million or $0.46 per share versus $58.8 billion or $0.34 per share during the first quarter of 2010, a 35% improvement on a per-share basis. During our fourth quarter conference call, we mentioned that we expected to earn approximately $9 million in performance-based manufacturer incentives over the following 2 quarters primarily related to Premium Luxury vehicles previously sold. 
Our first quarter gross profit and operating income were favorably impacted by $4.6 million due to the recognition of these incentives. We expect to recognize approximately $4.5 million in operating income related to these incentives in the second quarter of 2011.
First quarter revenue increased $474.5 million or 17% compared to the prior year. Gross profit improved by $57.8 million or 11%, while SG&A was up $34.3 million or 9% for the quarter. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 72.0% for the quarter. Excluding the benefit from the manufacturer incentives previously mentioned, it would have been 72.6%. This represents an improvement of over 80 basis points compared to the first quarter of 2010 and it also represents over 100 basis points sequential improvement, excluding the benefit from the incentives in both quarters. 
Although we achieved strong SG&A performance to date, there's are further long-term benefit to begin as we focus on technology and process improvements in our stores and in our shared service centers, as well as centralized procurement initiatives. 
Our scale and centralization efforts to date uniquely position us to take these next steps in SG&A improvements. 
Net new vehicles floor plan was a benefit of $4.7 million for the quarter, an improvement of $1.4 million compared to the $3.3 million benefit in the first quarter of 2010 due to an increase in corporate assistance as a result of higher new vehicle sales. Partially offset by an increase in Incorporate interest expense due to higher average point balances during the quarter. Non vehicle interest expense was $16.3 million up for the quarter, up from the $9 million reported in the first quarter of 2010 due to higher debt levels and increased percentage of fixed rate debt and increase spreads related to our refinancing in April of 2010.
During the quarter, we paid down $15 million under our revolving credit facility, resulting in $165 million of outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility at the end of the first quarter. Our first quarter non vehicle debt balance was $1.34 billion, an increase of $226 million compared to the first quarter of 2010, but a decrease of $11.8 million compared to the fourth quarter of 2010. 
LIBOR rates were relatively flat compared to the first quarter of 2010. The provision for income tax in the quarter was $44.2 million or 38.6%. During the first quarter, we repurchased approximately 1.8 million shares for $59 million at an average price of $32.84 per share. We ended the first quarter with 148.6 million shares outstanding and a $174 million board authorization remaining for future share repurchases. 
During the quarter, as previously disclosed, we acquired a Toyota store in the Fort Myers market for approximately $64 million. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $25 million and our CapEx estimate for the year remains at $140 million net of proceeds from related asset sales. 
Floor plan debt was approximately $1.65 billion at quarter end, down approximately $214 million from December 1 2010 in-line with inventory levels. We remain within the limits of our financial covenants with the leverage ratio of 2.27x at the end of the quarter. Our indebtedness number in this calculation is not on a net debt basis if we had applied the cash of our balance sheet plus cash available from used inventory flowing. To reduce debt, we would have lower the ratio to 2.0x compared to the limit of 3.25x. 
Our quarter end cash balance was $84 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity resulted in strong total liquidity of approximately $570 million at the end of March. The strength of our balance sheet and the discipline of our cost structure will enable us to manage through the challenges presented by the Japanese product constraints. We are well-positioned to continue to invest in our business and capitalize on the long-term recovery in the automotive market. Now let me turn you over to our President and Chief Operating Officer, Mike Maroone.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike and good morning. AutoNation delivered a strong performance in the quarter and I'll start by thanking our Associates for their commitment and dedication in making it happen. Customers were in the market and we were ready as evidenced by str
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike and good morning. AutoNation delivered a strong performance in the quarter and I'll start by thanking our Associates for their commitment and dedication in making it happen. 
Customers were in the market and we were ready as evidenced by strong year-over-year increases in new and used unit volume, making this the fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit growth for total retail volume. Revenue in total gross profit increased in all areas of our business and recorded an impressive operating margin of 4.2%.
Turning to detailed results. I'll begin with our segment performance. At $129 million, total segment income for the first quarter grew 22% or $23 million compared to the period a year ago with increases in all 3 segments as follows: Domestic segment income increased 34% to $43 million; Premium Luxury increased 18% to $55 million; and Import Segment income increased 15% to $58 million. As I continue my comments, we'll be in a same-store basis unless noted otherwise. 
During the first quarter, AutoNation retailed 54,200 new vehicles, an increase of 8,900 units or 20% compared to the period a year ago. First quarter new vehicle same-store revenue increased $286 million or 20% to $1.75 billion on increased volume, driven by stronger customer demand. 
A $2,266 gross profit for new vehicle retail was relatively flat compared to the period a year ago and gross profit as a percent of revenue of 7% was off by 10 basis points. This was driven by a decline in margins of the Import Segment due to the competitive environment, which was partially offset by the recognition of special performance-based manufacturing incentives which we discussed on our previous call. 
Excluding the $4.6 million of special performance-based manufacturing incentives in the quarter, gross profit for new vehicle retail was $2,181, a reduction of $91 or 4% and gross profit as a percent of revenue was 6.8%. Sequentially from Q4 to Q1, again excluding the special performance-based manufacture incentives, we saw an improvement in the gross profit for new vehicle retail at $18. 
At March 31, new vehicle days supply was 50 days or 40,800 units compared to 51 days a year ago and 63 days at December 31.
Next, used vehicles, where we're very pleased with our results. AutoNation retailed 41,300 used vehicles in the quarter, which drove a unit volume increase of 10% compared to the period a year ago and a used to new ratio of 0.76:1. 
As tight inventories and increasing demand moved prices higher, same-store retail used revenue was up 11% to $714 million and revenue per used vehicle retail of $17,300 increase $224 compared to the period a year ago. Same-store use vehicle gross profit of $73 million reflected an increase of 15% while gross profit per used vehicle retailed at $1,750, grew $78 or 5% compared to the period a year ago. Used vehicle gross profit as a percent of revenue at 10.1% grew 30 basis points.
I'd like to provide a quick update on our Value Vehicles Outlet, an initiatives in its early stages to retail value priced vehicles that we would have traditionally wholesaled. Today, we have 22 locations in operation, with 6 more planned by the end of Q3. We are very pleased with the continued growth of this program, which is an important part of our strategy to address industry supply constraints and meet market demand. 
Another important component is winning more trades, which we addressed by viewing every customer visit as a trade opportunity and ensuring our appraisal process that actively involves the customer is consistently executed. I'll also note that in the quarter, we moved nearly 12,000 used vehicles from originating stores to a more optimal location relative to turn and PVR. 
In continued experience, good success that retail with this program. At March 31, used vehicle days supply was 42 days in line with our adjusted targeted days supply.
For parts, service and collision compared to the period, compared to the quarter a year ago, same-store revenue of $557 million increased $19 million or 4%. We are very pleased to deliver another solid performance on the customer pay side where customer pay revenue grew year-over-year for the third consecutive quarter and was up 4% year-over-year for the second consecutive quarter. 
We had attribute the upward trend in customer pay revenue to improving market conditions and better execution in the service drive. Parts, service and collision gross profit of $239 million was up $2 million or 1% compared to a year ago, and the quarter increases of 2% in customer pay service gross and a 7% increase in internal gross, more than offset a 4% decline in warranty gross. 
Gross profit as a percent of revenue was up 120 basis points to 42.9% compared to a year-ago. we attribute this to a shift in mix toward internal as well as a shift within customer pay resulting from our initiatives to grow tires and maintenance to drive customer retention. I'll also note that the warranty comp in a period a year ago included the Toyota recalls.
Turning to F&I. Gross profit for vehicle retail of $1,137 remains strong but up slightly versus a year ago with improvements in the rate of product commissions, offset by product chargebacks and lower retrospective commission on vehicle service contract programs. 
The credit environment was again favorable compared to a year ago and stable sequentially. In the quarter, we noted key non prime and sub prime lenders were buying deeper year-over-year. 
At March 31, our store portfolio stood at 209 stores and 243 franchises, representing 31 brands in 15 states. Changes from our Q4 2010 call are the completion of the acquisition of Ft. Myers Toyota and the separation of franchises at 2 locations. One where we separated Mini from BMW Northern California, and the other where we separated Mitsubishi from Chevrolet in Houston. We remain confident regarding the long term outlook for our business and are continuing to invest in our future growth. 
Year-to-date, we've completed 8 of 16 major facility projects slated for 2011. We've opened 2 brand new state-of-the-art ad points for Mercedes Benz at Stanford and Central Florida, and Mercedes Benz of Coconut Creek in South Florida. Relocations to new ground up facilities include Leaseburg Honda, now called Honda of Dallas, Team Hyundai of Mall of Georgia and Mercedes Benz of Sarasota. 
We opened Fiat South Bay in Southern California after renovating an existing vacant facility and completed the extensive renovation of Mercedes Benz of Orlando and Mercedes Benz of Westmont in the Chicago market.
Looking ahead, we continue to seek acquisition opportunity that meet our market, brand and return on investment criteria. Before I close, I'd like to touch on how we are addressing the reduction in Japanese production. We've implemented a substantial number of tactical moves to address potential impacts with the goal of maximizing our inventories and optimizing gross. 
Our revised operating plan includes benchmarking and tactical adjustments of market pricing in new and used vehicles, increased acquisition of used inventory outside of auctions, a significant marketing shift to promote our broad selection of domestic and used inventory, as well as our fixed operation business and an aggressive management of variable expenses. With the full extent of the industry impact not yet known, we believe that our disciplined approach coupled with an operating model that's diversified by brand, geography and revenue stream, positions us well to successfully navigate the anticipated disruption.
In closing, in the quarter, AutoNation continue to drive topline growth and margin growth as well as delivered a record EPS in the first quarter in an industry selling rate of 13 million units. We did it with low associate turnover, high customer satisfaction, an disciplined cost structure and a 1 team, 1 goal spirit. I'd like to thank our Associates and share that we are very optimistic about the future of our company. And with that, I'll turn the call back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Our record of first quarter results demonstrate that consumers back reflect our ability to leverage our operating model and disciplined cost structure. Our diversified business model is resilient and adaptable. We're confident we can manage
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. Our record of first quarter results demonstrate that consumers back reflect our ability to leverage our operating model and disciplined cost structure. Our diversified business model is resilient and adaptable. We're confident we can manage through the challenges presented by the Japanese product constraints and continue to be optimistic about the long-term recovery of the U.S. auto market. With that, I'd like to open it up the call for questions. First question, please.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Patrick Archambault, Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from Patrick Archambault, Goldman Sachs.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the Japan impact, 2 questions. #1, can you give us a sense of how you see the timing impacting sales? In earlier call with a group 1 suggested that inventories might be good to sort of sustained a couple of months of sales without issues but by the thi
componenttext: On the Japan impact, 2 questions. #1, can you give us a sense of how you see the timing impacting sales? In earlier call with a group 1 suggested that inventories might be good to sort of sustained a couple of months of sales without issues but by the third quarters when we might see the impact. And then second to that, maybe just generally, how you think some of the supply issues that are happening are likely to impact pricing and margins for you guys going forward.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mike Jackson. As of March 1, Japanese had very good inventories in the U.S. around 6,000 units on the ground and we had an excellent pipeline coming from Japan and parts going to the U.S. factories to continue production. So that really says
componenttext: Yes, this is Mike Jackson. As of March 1, Japanese had very good inventories in the U.S. around 6,000 units on the ground and we had an excellent pipeline coming from Japan and parts going to the U.S. factories to continue production. So that really says that you have a good supply. Through April and May, you'll begin to see the first sign of disruption. I think then, the Japanese dealers are very skilled at working with lower inventories, they've done it for years so there can be significant inventory reduction before there is a meaningful impact on sales. But I think May, June, you'll begin to see a few of the disruption of the production and certainly July, there will be meaningful shortages of Japanese products. I think on the front end growth is and margins, we fully expected in the journey back to 16 million units and with increasing demand that we would be able to improve those margins in that journey. And I certainly believe in this period here, where there's going to be a significant differential between demand and supply, you will see improvement in front end margins. Maroone, maybe you can add to that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think you captured we have good supply today but we will feel pressured and what they do is we benchmark to market pricing. There's a lot of data out there and we will move our prices up as the market moves up. And we do think there's an opportuni
componenttext: Mike, I think you captured we have good supply today but we will feel pressured and what they do is we benchmark to market pricing. There's a lot of data out there and we will move our prices up as the market moves up. And we do think there's an opportunity.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just maybe 1 follow-up to that. It's kind of a very broad question, but how flexible do you think some of the buyers are, or most of the buyers are, I should say, for mid-volume floor products? Are these folks that you think you can get i
componenttext: Okay, great. And just maybe 1 follow-up to that. It's kind of a very broad question, but how flexible do you think some of the buyers are, or most of the buyers are, I should say, for mid-volume floor products? Are these folks that you think you can get into some of your other dealerships and competing brands during those periods of time when the product is tight or is the loyalty for that group strong enough that, that might be difficult?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think what we were saying is that the demand is there for a much higher selling rate but the supply will not be there. And I think in Mike and I's 40 years of experience in this business, I don't think I've ever said that in the auto industry. So this i
componenttext: I think what we were saying is that the demand is there for a much higher selling rate but the supply will not be there. And I think in Mike and I's 40 years of experience in this business, I don't think I've ever said that in the auto industry. So this is an unprecedented supply restraint and to continued the conversation in all our discussion with the domestic and the German, there's a sense that they're working hard to maintain their original production plant, but they have given us no indication yet that they are able to increase production beyond the original plant but they are dealing with part supply issues from the Japanese also. So it's really a supply constrained situation. So I'm not sure the availability is going -- at the Domestic, its going to be able to breach the gap with the shortage of the Japanese and the total year. So it's clearly going to be a margin situation. I will say though in principle, the Domestic have a much more attractive offering than they did 5 to 10 years ago, both from design, quality and certainly from fuel efficiency. So they're well positioned to be attractive to the Japanese traffic. And I think you'll have a compelling offer for them. But how much of that can really occur? I can't say. And that's the reason why we reduced our forecast for our industry sales to the mid-12 million. From today's perspective, I just don't see where the production is to support something higher than that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay terrific. Thanks, that's very helpful.
componenttext: Okay terrific. Thanks, that's very helpful.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Rick Nelson of Stephens.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Rick Nelson of Stephens.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think earlier, you had talked about your expectation that we would see a 30% to 50% reduction in production from the Japanese OEMs. Are you still comfortable with that estimate? And your view changed at all in the duration.
componenttext: I think earlier, you had talked about your expectation that we would see a 30% to 50% reduction in production from the Japanese OEMs. Are you still comfortable with that estimate? And your view changed at all in the duration.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rick, last time we spoke was on a sales call, 30% to 50% in 3 to 4 months. So 30% is out the window. Its 50% somewhere around that, plus/minus somewhat and it's not 3 to 4 months, its 3 to 7 months. And so if they are back on stride in the October, Novemb
componenttext: Rick, last time we spoke was on a sales call, 30% to 50% in 3 to 4 months. So 30% is out the window. Its 50% somewhere around that, plus/minus somewhat and it's not 3 to 4 months, its 3 to 7 months. And so if they are back on stride in the October, November with "normal production" of parts and vehicles, then you have to add 6 weeks to that to get it into the market. So we live in the real world. So on a shipment basis, to begin to rebuild inventory, you're into next year. So that's the reason that we have said there's going to be supply constrained year. So that means we have to do more work on the margin side, which we will. But from today's perspective, I don't see how the production is going to be there to support something above the mid-12 million level.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then you comment -- thank you for that, but can you comment on the used car business, how you see that impact about the supply constraints? More demand for used cars but higher sourcing cost because we're going to auction?
componenttext: And then you comment -- thank you for that, but can you comment on the used car business, how you see that impact about the supply constraints? More demand for used cars but higher sourcing cost because we're going to auction?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rick, it's Mike Maroone. I think there's a tremendous opportunity in use and we're positioned to take advantage of it. We moved our inventories up. Our goal is to gain supply at the doors, we call it, in our dealerships to try and win more appraisals. We
componenttext: Rick, it's Mike Maroone. I think there's a tremendous opportunity in use and we're positioned to take advantage of it. We moved our inventories up. Our goal is to gain supply at the doors, we call it, in our dealerships to try and win more appraisals. We are aggressively going after every single appraisal. I don't think our business model is just standing at the auction and buying large numbers of vehicle, so I think there is opportunity. Certainly that prices are strong. We changed the number of our policies in aging and wholesale and are really trying to get our inventories up, which we've done successfully. I think its a big opportunity, both in the volume side and the margin side.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And 1 more comment, this is Mike Jackson. I will note that both GM and Ford have confirmed, there's our outlook of $13 million to $13.4 million and if you do the math, the only way you can get there, that means GM and Ford are significantly increasing pro
componenttext: And 1 more comment, this is Mike Jackson. I will note that both GM and Ford have confirmed, there's our outlook of $13 million to $13.4 million and if you do the math, the only way you can get there, that means GM and Ford are significantly increasing production above plant or else, the math doesn't work. So they may know something I don't know that could well be, but from what they're telling us as far as what they're going to produce, there's been no increase in their production plan. But I will note that they are confirming $13 million to $13.4 million and they could know something I don't.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And can I ask you about Toyota allocations? We have the things have really come to it. Including on a week to week basis and any color there would be helpful.
componenttext: And can I ask you about Toyota allocations? We have the things have really come to it. Including on a week to week basis and any color there would be helpful.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rick, again, its Mike Maroone. I'll share your view. I don't know if they've come to a grinding halt but there's very little allocation of product. As Mike Jackson said, we have very solid inventory, probably above average inventory on March 1 and a very
componenttext: Rick, again, its Mike Maroone. I'll share your view. I don't know if they've come to a grinding halt but there's very little allocation of product. As Mike Jackson said, we have very solid inventory, probably above average inventory on March 1 and a very strong pipeline. Of course, the pipeline has not been disrupted its the future production that is disrupted. So we are in decent shape today but I do not see the pipeline refilling too much and we stand by our 50% reduction of normal production.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Next question is coming from John Murphy, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next question is coming from John Murphy, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your comments on the Japan situation have been very helpful but Mike, I know GM and Ford are saying 1 thing, the Japanese are saying another thing, but if you can't comment on what you do know, what you're hearing in your dealerships, are you hearing any
componenttext: Your comments on the Japan situation have been very helpful but Mike, I know GM and Ford are saying 1 thing, the Japanese are saying another thing, but if you can't comment on what you do know, what you're hearing in your dealerships, are you hearing any increased car shopping, particularly we've got GM coming out with the Sonic and they had the Cruze last year and the Ford has the VS and the Focus. They really do have some good competitive products here at a time the Japanese are going to be out of product. I'm just wondering if you're hearing that buzz or your sales guys are maybe seeing we have another product that might fit your needs. Just trying to understand what's going on in the short term or what you're hearing. And then maybe also if that might translate into some potential longer-term market share shifts as they get people into these good vehicles.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, I fully agree that the offering from the Domestics is far more compelling than it was 5 to 10 years ago and it's spot-on on issues as far as design, quality, content and most importantly, fuel efficiency. So it really is a different game. And there'
componenttext: John, I fully agree that the offering from the Domestics is far more compelling than it was 5 to 10 years ago and it's spot-on on issues as far as design, quality, content and most importantly, fuel efficiency. So it really is a different game. And there's no question that the Domestics will gain share this year. We're saying the price is going to be smaller because of production constraints, the big production constraints are with the Japanese. And Domestics have confirmed that they will hit through their original production plan with content and configuration issues but they'll hit the original production plan so they will take share, so I think the door is open. What we haven't heard from the Domestics though is any statement or any indication that they're able to increase production beyond original plan. So that's where the situation sits at the moment. If they are alternately able to do that, I think develop, then I think the door is open for an even larger share step by the Domestics. Mr. Maroone, do you want to add anything?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I'd just say that our Domestic allocations has been robust. We just had a big allocation yesterday from GM, which we're always looking for more in this kind of situation. I think in terms of car shopping, John, I think its just a little bit early beca
componenttext: No, I'd just say that our Domestic allocations has been robust. We just had a big allocation yesterday from GM, which we're always looking for more in this kind of situation. I think in terms of car shopping, John, I think its just a little bit early because of there is sufficient import inventory on the ground. I think that car shopping will certainly heat up in May, June and July.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's an important point. Again in the retail world, so far nothing has changed. We have excellent supply of Japanese products through month end and its really end of May before you even see the first indication of disruption at the store level.
componenttext: Yes, that's an important point. Again in the retail world, so far nothing has changed. We have excellent supply of Japanese products through month end and its really end of May before you even see the first indication of disruption at the store level.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then second question is on SG&A. The 72% SG&A as a percent of growth is the lowest level it's been in 4 years now in the first quarter. So there's been great performance there. I mean, are we still looking at a period where the second or third quarter
componenttext: And then second question is on SG&A. The 72% SG&A as a percent of growth is the lowest level it's been in 4 years now in the first quarter. So there's been great performance there. I mean, are we still looking at a period where the second or third quarter, we can skip over those, but I think in the fourth quarter beyond into next year when hopefully the world normalizes eventually, that you could be significantly below the levels that you have been before, meaning that you could break through that 70% level and maybe stay through that in a normalized market below that, I should say.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've been below 70% before. In 2005, we operated in the 69% range and I think as volume comes back, its very hard to get back there.
componenttext: Yes, we've been below 70% before. In 2005, we operated in the 69% range and I think as volume comes back, its very hard to get back there.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on share buybacks, are there any other limits other than the debt to the debt covenant that you mentioned on the call or is that the only limiting factor we should look for technically on share buybacks?
componenttext: And then just lastly on share buybacks, are there any other limits other than the debt to the debt covenant that you mentioned on the call or is that the only limiting factor we should look for technically on share buybacks?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: From a technical perspective, it's merely technical, is we have $175 million versus $104 million left on the Board authorization but obviously, that's up to the Board to amend and increase as they see fit.
componenttext: From a technical perspective, it's merely technical, is we have $175 million versus $104 million left on the Board authorization but obviously, that's up to the Board to amend and increase as they see fit.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Brian Sponheimer, Gabelli and Company.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Brian Sponheimer, Gabelli and Company.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking my calls. Just 1 question back on demand in the Japanese issue. Any sense that you could see customer pull forward into this quarter, where customers are becoming concerned about the availability as they start to see some constraint on s
componenttext: Thanks for taking my calls. Just 1 question back on demand in the Japanese issue. Any sense that you could see customer pull forward into this quarter, where customers are becoming concerned about the availability as they start to see some constraint on supply looking in the summer months?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, I really don't think so. Because the situation is already going to begin in mid-May and there's not a lot of time for the customer -- if the customer is going to rush the quarter, you're already going to have supply issues in the quarter. So I don'
componenttext: Brian, I really don't think so. Because the situation is already going to begin in mid-May and there's not a lot of time for the customer -- if the customer is going to rush the quarter, you're already going to have supply issues in the quarter. So I don't see that happening in a meaningful way. I mean, you make some of that sound anecdotally but I don't think there's going to be enough supply that you're able to jam the second quarter, if you will, in a land rush to get the Japanese product before they run out, I don't see that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hey, this is indeed, I have to be clear, an unprecedented situation where, "okay, we've had an occasional strike with a domestic manufacturer here, but we've never had a whole manufacturing segment shut down like this to this extent." So we'll have to see
componenttext: Hey, this is indeed, I have to be clear, an unprecedented situation where, "okay, we've had an occasional strike with a domestic manufacturer here, but we've never had a whole manufacturing segment shut down like this to this extent." So we'll have to see how it develops but I don't expect that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And if you're taking about 300,000 units from your 2011 sales estimates, would it be correct to think that those 300,000 units simply push into 2011 or some are lost to the used market?
componenttext: Thank you. And if you're taking about 300,000 units from your 2011 sales estimates, would it be correct to think that those 300,000 units simply push into 2011 or some are lost to the used market?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think they are pushed into the following year, 2012. And the math is if we sort of do the production disruption, we come to a loss of 600,000 or 700,000 units for the Japanese. You can take Japanese inventory down 300,000-some units. The Japanese de
componenttext: No, I think they are pushed into the following year, 2012. And the math is if we sort of do the production disruption, we come to a loss of 600,000 or 700,000 units for the Japanese. You can take Japanese inventory down 300,000-some units. The Japanese dealers have clearly shown the ability to work with lean inventories before and so we're taking the difference of that 300,000 out of our planning with a clear statement that demand is higher but I don't know where the production is going to come to cover it.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just 1 more, if I may. Just on credit availability and credit score. Do you have any metrics for FICO scores during the quarter? Any change of credit mix or loan availability versus, say, 3 months ago and 12 months ago?
componenttext: Okay, and just 1 more, if I may. Just on credit availability and credit score. Do you have any metrics for FICO scores during the quarter? Any change of credit mix or loan availability versus, say, 3 months ago and 12 months ago?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brian, no real change in FICO scores. I think what we did call out is certainly, a deeper buying at sub prime, but the quality of the buyer hasn't deteriorated. It seems to be pretty stable.
componenttext: Brian, no real change in FICO scores. I think what we did call out is certainly, a deeper buying at sub prime, but the quality of the buyer hasn't deteriorated. It seems to be pretty stable.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you for taking my calls.
componenttext: Thank you for taking my calls.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011

componenttext: Our last question. Our next caller is Matt Nemer of Wells Fargo.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking my question. So first, I wanted to see a step back and ask probably a fairly elementary question. But if a vehicle is short on supplier at a stock either in the past or currently in something on sale like the Prius, do customers tend to
componenttext: Thanks for taking my question. So first, I wanted to see a step back and ask probably a fairly elementary question. But if a vehicle is short on supplier at a stock either in the past or currently in something on sale like the Prius, do customers tend to wait for it to come back in, do they change models or will they switch to nearly new and do you have any stats on that?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Matt, it's Mike Maroone. I don't think we've got states. But the precedent that we really seen in the business is people buying from an incoming pipeline. We haven't had a situation where the pipeline has been dry so I think it's difficult to say how cust
componenttext: Matt, it's Mike Maroone. I don't think we've got states. But the precedent that we really seen in the business is people buying from an incoming pipeline. We haven't had a situation where the pipeline has been dry so I think it's difficult to say how customers are going to react.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay and then just a few questions on the used car business. We've heard some reports and that has been significant intra- quarter appreciation and used vehicle prices, particularly in the month of March and in April. Just wondering if you could p
componenttext: Got it. Okay and then just a few questions on the used car business. We've heard some reports and that has been significant intra- quarter appreciation and used vehicle prices, particularly in the month of March and in April. Just wondering if you could pick up some inventory on that based on your current inventory, relative to pay more in the market as well, but could we see a period short term of potentially much higher used vehicle margins?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone again. I think there's an opportunity for greater margin. You are correct, we did see auction price movement in late February and March as fuel prices went up. We saw some double-digit appreciation in fuel-efficient vehicles and I think
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone again. I think there's an opportunity for greater margin. You are correct, we did see auction price movement in late February and March as fuel prices went up. We saw some double-digit appreciation in fuel-efficient vehicles and I think there is opportunity. We do try in generally keep our inventory lean. We're normally in the 35- to 37-day supply, we're now targeting 42 to 44 to try and take advantage of the opportunity on used. And so I think there's a margin opportunity both from your existing inventory and then again with us, we have a lot of opportunity to win used vehicles at our dealerships. That's our intention and if we can do that, I think it really speaks well for a way to mitigate some of the disruption from the new Japanese business.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up on that, how do you increase appraisal buy rates at the stores? Is there a change in the appraisal process or maybe you can give us a sense for what you're doing there.
componenttext: And just a follow up on that, how do you increase appraisal buy rates at the stores? Is there a change in the appraisal process or maybe you can give us a sense for what you're doing there.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got a very defined process that we've used that actively involves the customers to review the vehicle. That's not new, but certainly we are looking for improved execution there. What we do is we measure the number of customer visits then we lo
componenttext: Well, we've got a very defined process that we've used that actively involves the customers to review the vehicle. That's not new, but certainly we are looking for improved execution there. What we do is we measure the number of customer visits then we look at the appraisals, then look at what the appraisals we want, we've got the technology to do that. We look at it every single day and we benchmark our associates and just trying to raise the awareness of the amount of opportunities from customer visits. So we want to get more vehicles appraised, we want the customers know very clearly that whether or not they buy a vehicle for us although we would like them to buy a vehicle from us, we would like to buy their trades. So there's a series of both merchandising and process execution that we think we can improve our performance there and we've been doing that for the last 3 to 4 weeks and I think we've been successful, we've got a really used car team out in the field.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just 1 last 1 on used cars, you mentioned that you moved 12,000 vehicles in the quarter, which is about Â¼ of your volume. Is any of that by customer request or is that all on inbound appraisals? And then can you measure the impact to gross as th
componenttext: And then just 1 last 1 on used cars, you mentioned that you moved 12,000 vehicles in the quarter, which is about Â¼ of your volume. Is any of that by customer request or is that all on inbound appraisals? And then can you measure the impact to gross as those vehicles net of transportation expense?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, some of it is customer request because we do have a virtual inventory. So there are times that we'll move it from customer convenience. But what we really do is use some software programs that say, "Here's where you can get highest and best
componenttext: First of all, some of it is customer request because we do have a virtual inventory. So there are times that we'll move it from customer convenience. But what we really do is use some software programs that say, "Here's where you can get highest and best value for that vehicle." We then move it. We used to wait several weeks before we move it to give the trading store an opportunity to retail it. Now with this disruption, we're moving vehicles day 1 to their highest and best use. We believe when we do that, we can turn the vehicle in 4 to 5 days quicker and we can turn it for higher gross margins. So it's done very strategically, we use software to do it and I think it's been a real successful. It allows us to pay more for the car and it also allows us to retail the vehicle quicker and hopefully with more margin.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, sounds interesting. Thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, sounds interesting. Thanks very much.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: The last question is coming from Colin Langan of UBS.
componenttext: The last question is coming from Colin Langan of UBS.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks for taking my question. Do you have any indication how this month is trending? I mean, you said inventory is not an issue until next month, so is it staying consistent with what we saw last month? And also regarding margins potentially
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for taking my question. Do you have any indication how this month is trending? I mean, you said inventory is not an issue until next month, so is it staying consistent with what we saw last month? And also regarding margins potentially improving in the near term, has there been a benefit at the end of March or in April so far, is that a trend that has started to occur?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we report our sales every month. We're 1 of the few automotive retail companies that do that, so I think it's next Wednesday. Next Wednesday, we'll have our results. It's always -- so much happened in the last week of the month that it can really ch
componenttext: Well, we report our sales every month. We're 1 of the few automotive retail companies that do that, so I think it's next Wednesday. Next Wednesday, we'll have our results. It's always -- so much happened in the last week of the month that it can really change what would be correct to say today. So I would really prefer to get the discipline of giving you that report when the month is done and we know in full what we are talking about.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And on the margin side, is there an improvement?
componenttext: And on the margin side, is there an improvement?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Same statement could apply.
componenttext: Same statement could apply.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then any comment on the improvement in used margins? It sounds like the improvement in auction values helps. Does that mean these levels sustainable in the Q1 or is it more of a temporary because some of the price of inventory revolving has rose?
componenttext: And then any comment on the improvement in used margins? It sounds like the improvement in auction values helps. Does that mean these levels sustainable in the Q1 or is it more of a temporary because some of the price of inventory revolving has rose?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. I believe that it is sustainable. We work hard to improve our processes. Certainly in a strong used car market with high demand and limited supply, I think there's opportunity. So as far out as we can see, we don't see the used vehicle
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. I believe that it is sustainable. We work hard to improve our processes. Certainly in a strong used car market with high demand and limited supply, I think there's opportunity. So as far out as we can see, we don't see the used vehicle market doing anything but getting better and I think there is margin opportunity there, yes.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just 1 last 1, certain back to the near-term disruption but what would be the impact if we do see a major shift from trucks to cars? I mean, are you equally profitable on both the products on a dealer level or is there a margin benefit from high
componenttext: Okay. And just 1 last 1, certain back to the near-term disruption but what would be the impact if we do see a major shift from trucks to cars? I mean, are you equally profitable on both the products on a dealer level or is there a margin benefit from higher in cars?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: First, we talk about gas prices. So far, we've seen a migration towards fuel efficiency that can be exemplified by the fact that the split between cars and trucks that was 50-50 for us in January, it moved to 52% in February, 55% in March. That is not com
componenttext: First, we talk about gas prices. So far, we've seen a migration towards fuel efficiency that can be exemplified by the fact that the split between cars and trucks that was 50-50 for us in January, it moved to 52% in February, 55% in March. That is not comparable to what happened in the '08 where it spiked over 60% in a very short period of time. We have not seen a significant impact on trading values or residual values of trucks or large cars as we did in '08 where those vehicles took a 15to 20% hit. And I think the number where people really overact or panic or freak out is indeed the higher than $4 a gallon, it's probably $4.50 to $5 a gallon, something like that. So it's a very manageable situation at the moment. Industry is much more better prepared. Every manufacturer is there with fuel-efficient vehicles. Inventories are balanced. So it's a very orderly transition towards fuel efficiency and we probably have another $0.50 a gallon to $1 a gallon to get something that would be comparable in '08.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you very much.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you everyone for your time today. Were very appreciative. Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you everyone for your time today. Were very appreciative. Thank you.
