headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Vivek Aalok for Himanshu Patel this morning from JPMorgan. I had a couple of quick questions. One on used vehicle sales, it seemed that used vehicle sales slowed down in the quarter and it was probably partially understandable given the order soft
componenttext: This is Vivek Aalok for Himanshu Patel this morning from JPMorgan. I had a couple of quick questions. One on used vehicle sales, it seemed that used vehicle sales slowed down in the quarter and it was probably partially understandable given the order softness in consumer demand that we had in the quarter. But do you have any early read on July used vehicle sales, maybe you saw some sequential improvement. And secondly, did you see -- do you expect any growth as we move forward, and what kind of growth there should we expect as we move into second half?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. I think the used vehicle business slowed down as the new vehicle business did slightly, and really it was slower growth. We did grow on a same-store basis of 3% in volume, but 14% in gross. So I think that it did move in line with the n
componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. I think the used vehicle business slowed down as the new vehicle business did slightly, and really it was slower growth. We did grow on a same-store basis of 3% in volume, but 14% in gross. So I think that it did move in line with the new. I think the used vehicle business will continue to be strong. It's an excellent alternative for value conscious buyers, and we continue to invest in that segment. In terms of the July business, we generally don't comment on current quarter, but I will tell you the business is holding up well and we are very pleased with our 14% improvement in gross.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And secondly, I may have missed it, but did you break down parts of recent revenue growth into individual buckets, warranty, customer pay, et cetera?
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And secondly, I may have missed it, but did you break down parts of recent revenue growth into individual buckets, warranty, customer pay, et cetera?

componenttextpreview: We do. And from a gross point of view, our customer pay business was up 1, warranty was down 6, collision was up 5.
componenttext: We do. And from a gross point of view, our customer pay business was up 1, warranty was down 6, collision was up 5.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Collision was up 5, okay. And finally, on your used vehicle gross margin outlook in the second half, we may see some pressure on used vehicle prices as we move into second half as new vehicle sales pick up. Do you expect some pressure on your used vehicle
componenttext: Collision was up 5, okay. And finally, on your used vehicle gross margin outlook in the second half, we may see some pressure on used vehicle prices as we move into second half as new vehicle sales pick up. Do you expect some pressure on your used vehicle gross margin?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that the reason that we try and keep our vehicle inventories around a one-month supply or a little bit more, is to deal with those kinds of situations. There is always some seasonal adjustments in every summer toward the end of the summer, you see
componenttext: I think that the reason that we try and keep our vehicle inventories around a one-month supply or a little bit more, is to deal with those kinds of situations. There is always some seasonal adjustments in every summer toward the end of the summer, you see some -- you see the market change a little bit and I think we'll be ready and be responsive to that change. So I don't think you'll see anything abnormal this year but certainly, there's seasonality in used vehicle pricing.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually just building on the used question. The used-to-new ratio is quite high. Clearly, that market plus the efforts you've had, you've put into it in terms of building inventories and capabilities have worked. Can you tell us a little bit about how yo
componenttext: Actually just building on the used question. The used-to-new ratio is quite high. Clearly, that market plus the efforts you've had, you've put into it in terms of building inventories and capabilities have worked. Can you tell us a little bit about how you expect that ratio to perform going forward. I mean, clearly, as new recovers, there's going to be some share taken away from new and one would expect that business to slow but then again, right, you have all these things that you've done that position you better in that business relative to a year ago. So just kind of thinking about the trade-off there?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Patrick, it's Mike Maroone. We're confident that we can continue to drive volume on the used vehicle side. Our current quarter was 0.83:1. A year ago, we were 0.78 and I think the real difference is the growth we've had in what we call the VVOs the Value
componenttext: Patrick, it's Mike Maroone. We're confident that we can continue to drive volume on the used vehicle side. Our current quarter was 0.83:1. A year ago, we were 0.78 and I think the real difference is the growth we've had in what we call the VVOs the Value Vehicle Outlets. So we're really looking to retail more and wholesale less and I'm confident we can sustain that trend so that -- there's a lot of pieces to the used car business, but a certified pre-owned is also an important segment that generally runs about 1/3 of the business and so we are pushing that segment across all brands as well as running the VVO locations that are now up to 26, and we'll continue to expand that. So I think you'll see us continue to push on that number. I think there is some more upside, it's really about retail execution and the ability to get the right products at the right price at the right time.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just one more, I guess your SG&A as a percentage of gross was $71.6 million I believe, I think you said that the hail if I understood you correctly, was maybe about a point on that. So you would have been closer to $70.6 million. Thinking
componenttext: Okay, great. And just one more, I guess your SG&A as a percentage of gross was $71.6 million I believe, I think you said that the hail if I understood you correctly, was maybe about a point on that. So you would have been closer to $70.6 million. Thinking about what did you guys do, kind of on a temporary basis to help you bring that down in the face of all the Japan-related stuff in terms of cutting advertising and things like that, that may come back in subsequent quarters, or is this kind of a level that you guys can further build on? I mean, I know you said that ultimately down the road, you could even be below $70 million?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Patrick, it's Mike Short. We look for continued improvement in this ratio going forward. It's one of our core strategies to maintain this level of disciplined financial management, we will certainly continue to do that and leverage some of the fixed
componenttext: Yes, Patrick, it's Mike Short. We look for continued improvement in this ratio going forward. It's one of our core strategies to maintain this level of disciplined financial management, we will certainly continue to do that and leverage some of the fixed costs within SG&A. As time goes on, I would say, in terms of temporary things, I think there were some areas where we pulled back in certain areas of advertising but I wouldn't -- by the same token, there were other areas where we spent a little bit more. So I wouldn't characterize the nature of anything that we did in the quarter as kind of short-term cuts that are going to come back in the future. I think it's just part of the ongoing strategy for AutoNation.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's third quarter 2011 conference call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Financi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to AutoNation's third quarter 2011 conference call. Leading our call today will be Mike Jackson, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Maroone, our President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Short, our Chief Financial Officer. Following their remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Kate Kaiser and I will also be available by phone following the call to address any additional questions that you may have.
Before we begin, let me read our brief statement regarding forward-looking comments and the use of non-GAAP financial measures. Certain statements and information on this call will constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements involve risks, which may cause the actual results or performance to differ materially from expectations. Additional discussions of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially are contained in our SEC filings. Certain non-GAAP financial measures, as defined under SEC rules, may be discussed on this call. Reconciliations are provided in our press release, which is available on our website at www.autonation.com.
And now, I'll turn the call over to AutoNation's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today, we reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.48, a record for third quarter results, up 23% compared to the $0.39 in the third quarter of 2010. Operating income increased 19% to $144 millio
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us. Today, we reported earnings per share from continuing operations of $0.48, a record for third quarter results, up 23% compared to the $0.39 in the third quarter of 2010. Operating income increased 19% to $144 million compared to the period a year ago. Third quarter 2011 revenue totaled $3.5 billion compared to $3.3 billion in the year-ago period, an increase of 7%, driven primarily by higher new and used vehicle average selling prices. Based on CNW Research Data, in the third quarter, total U.S. industry new retail vehicle unit sales increased 1%. In the third quarter, AutoNation's total new vehicle unit sales were flat, and on same-store basis, declined 2% as of the Japanese earthquake affected availability of vehicles produced by the Japanese manufacturers. 
This quarter, we once again demonstrated that our diversified business model is the right strategy, as well as our ability to rapidly adapt to change and execute effectively in a changing marketplace. In light of the Japanese supply constraints, we adjusted our operating plan to optimize our inventories and maximize gross profit. While shipments from the Japanese manufacturers improved in the third quarter, inventory levels for these vehicles remained constrained. We would expect that the improving supply environment will result in sequentially lower margins on these vehicles in the fourth quarter. I'll now turn the call over to Chief Financial Officer, Mike Short.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the third quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $71 million or $0.48 per share versus $59 million or $0.39 per share during the third quarter of 2010, a 23% improvement o
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. For the third quarter, we reported net income from continuing operations of $71 million or $0.48 per share versus $59 million or $0.39 per share during the third quarter of 2010, a 23% improvement on a per-share basis. There were no adjustments in net income in either period. 
Last quarter, we indicated that we expected to receive the remaining incentives under the premium luxury program during the second half of 2011. We did not receive any of these incentives during the third quarter, but expect to receive approximately $2 million in the fourth quarter of 2011. This compares to gross profit from incentives of $13 million received in the fourth quarter of 2010. 
Third quarter revenue increased $233 million or 7% compared to prior year, and gross profit improved by $30 million or 5% for the quarter. SG&A as a percentage of gross profit was 71.5% for the quarter, which represents a 240 basis point improvement compared to the year ago period. 
Net new vehicle floorplan was a benefit of $6.6 million for the quarter, an increase of $1.9 million compared to the $4.7 million benefit in the third quarter of 2010. This improvement was due to lower floorplan interest expense, driven by lower credit spreads compared to the prior year period. Floorplan assistance rates also increased compared to the third quarter of 2010. Floorplan debt was approximately $1.51 billion at quarter end, a decrease of approximately $162 million from June 30, 2011, in line with inventory levels. 
Non-vehicle interest expense was $16.4 million for the quarter, an increase compared to the $16.1 million we reported in the third quarter of 2010 due to higher debt levels. During the quarter, we borrowed $25 million under our revolving credit facility, resulting in $300 million of outstanding borrowings under the revolving credit facility at the end of September. 
Our third quarter non-vehicle debt balance was $1.49 billion, an increase of $107 million compared to the third quarter of 2010. The provision for income tax for the quarter was $45 million or 38.8%. By comparison, this in the third quarter of 2010 was 37.5%, which reflected the benefit of certain favorable tax adjustments. 
From July 1, 2011, through October 19, 2011, we repurchased 7.2 million shares for $247 million at an average price of $34.45 per share. Today, we announced that our board authorized a repurchase of up to an additional $250 million of AutoNation common stock. AutoNation has $316 million now remaining in board authorization for share repurchase.  As of October 19, there were 139.9 million shares outstanding. 
We incurred $50 million in capital expenditures for the quarter, reflecting our commitment to continue to reinvest in the business. For the full year, we expect to incur $145 million in CapEx net of proceeds from related asset sales. We remain within the limits of our financial covenants. Our leverage ratio at September 30 was 2.38x or 2.11x on a net debt basis, including used floorplan availability compared to our limit of 3.25x. Our quarter end cash balance was $67 million, which combined with our additional borrowing capacity, resulted in a healthy total liquidity of $446 million at the end of September. 
Our robust balance sheet, strong cash flow generation and disciplined cost structure position us to continue to invest in our business. We remain focused on actively allocating capital to maximize shareholder returns. Now, let me turn you over to our President and Chief Operating Officer, Mike Maroone.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning. In the quarter, we continue to navigate the Japanese product disruption and economic uncertainty while growing both revenue and total gross profit. We delivered strong new vehicle and financial insurance gross margins and a
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning. In the quarter, we continue to navigate the Japanese product disruption and economic uncertainty while growing both revenue and total gross profit. We delivered strong new vehicle and financial insurance gross margins and a solid operating margin of 4.1%, a 40 basis point improvement year-over-year. 
Third quarter total segment income of $134 million grew 22% or $24 million compared to the period a year ago, with increases across all 3 segments. $65 million import segment income increased $14 million or 27% for the second quarter. This improvement is attributable, in large part, to increased new vehicle gross profit as inventory supplier remained constrained. 
The Domestic segment, at $47 million, increased $4 million or 10%, and the most stable segment, Premium Luxury, increased $2 million or 4% to $50 million. 
As I continue my comments, we'll be on a same-store basis unless noted otherwise. In the quarter, AutoNation retailed 55,000 new vehicles, up 2% year-over-year for same stores, compared to the industry that was up 1% at retail according to CNW. Even with extremely tight supply of higher demand models in all segments, we realized increased unit sales of 12% in the Domestic segment and 11% in the Premium Luxury segment on a total store basis. However, these increases were largely offset by a drop of 10% in import volume due to the ongoing effect of the Japanese inventory disruption. 
From a geography standpoint, Texas continue as our strongest market in the quarter. Florida, in our Western markets where recovery for more heavily impacted by the Japanese inventory disruption due to the higher mix of large import stores in these states. At $1.8 billion, new vehicle same-store revenue increased $62 million or 4% driven by increased revenue per vehicle retailed, which at $33,000 was up $1,900 or 6%, with increases in each segment. 
Gross profit for new vehicle retailed of $2,456 reflects an increase of $462 or 23% with improvement across all 3 segments. New vehicle gross profit as a percent of revenue was 7.3%, an increase of 100 basis points compared to the period a year ago. We attribute these improvements to the tactical plan implemented in the second quarter in response to Japanese inventory disruptions. We also continued to utilize our proprietary web-based pricing tool described during our second quarter call.  The tool captured various market pricing metrics and establish as a target in for prices by model. 
While we are very pleased with strong new vehicle margin growth, we expect some moderation as inventory levels continue to normalize. I'll also note that in the fourth quarter of 2010, our new vehicle margin benefited by about $250 on a per vehicle basis from additional performance-based manufacturer incentives. 
In September 30, new vehicle days supply was 45 days or 34,000 units compared to 57 days or 42,000 units a year ago. Looking ahead, our new vehicle inventory will continue to build throughout the fourth quarter, and we expect to reach normal levels in the first quarter of 2012. 
Turning to used vehicles, AutoNation retailed 43,000 on a same-store basis in the quarter, up 1% versus the period a year ago. Our used-to-new ratio in the quarter was 0.79, up from 0.76 year ago. Same-store retail used vehicle revenue of $776 million increased $33 million or 5% year-over-year. Revenue per used vehicle retail of $17,600 was up $560 or 3% as industry used vehicle prices remain strong in the quarter due to consumer demand and tight inventory availability. 
Same-store retail used vehicle gross profit of $66 million declined 2%, and gross profit per vehicle retailed at $1,529, was up 3% compared to the period a year ago. In the quarter, we noted a 6% increase in appraisals and a 7% increase in trade-ins acquired compared to the period a year ago, with a close ratio of 47%. I'll also note that we continue to move used vehicles to locations that will drive a faster turn and higher gross.  In the period, we moved nearly 11,000 vehicles with good success at retail. 
At September 30, used vehicle days supply was 43 days compared to 46 days a year ago and 47 days at June 30. During the quarter, we've reduce our used vehicle days supply to better prepare for seasonal pricing changes, and we experienced moderate wholesale loss. 
Same-store parts service and collision revenues of $569 million increased $5 million or 1% compared to the quarter a year ago. We're pleased with our results in customer pay, where revenue increased up 3% to $193 million, marks the fifth consecutive second quarter of year-over-year increases. This gain was more than offset by a significant decline in warranty revenue where our repair order count trap up about 10% year-over-year. We attribute this to the ongoing trend of fewer units in operations and improved vehicle quality. 
Gross profit of $238 million declined $8 million or 3% compared to the quarter a year ago. Customer pay gross profit grew by 2%. However, gains here were offset by a 15% decline in warranty gross profit. 
As for pay, gross profit was up for the fifth consecutive quarter year-over-year, driven in part by aggressive efforts to grow tires sales and other lower margins service offerings increase in customer retention. I'll also note, there was one last working day in the quarter compared to the year ago. Turning to F&I, we continue to be pleased with our industry-leading performance. Total gross profit in the quarter was $119 million, an increase of $7 million or 7% compared to a year ago. Same-store gross profit for vehicle retailed was $1,200, $1,214 per vehicle, up $84 or 7% compared to a year ago. Results continue to be driven by solid process execution, which drove improved rate and product commissions. 
We continue to benefit from our strong preferred lender network for prime, nonprime and subprime, as well as strong product penetration. The credit environment was solid and stable in the quarter. 
At September 30, our store portfolio numbered 214 stores and 257 franchises, representing 32 brands in 15 states. In the quarter, we opened Go Fiat in Denver and added 2 Smart franchises to existing Mercedes-Benz stores. Our corporate real estate team is also wrapping up several other significant projects that are slated for completion by year end. 
Looking ahead, we are actively seeking acquisition opportunities that meet our market plan and return on investment criteria. 
In closing, in the quarter, we delivered a 19% increase in operating income, along with record third quarter EPS. We did it with best effort customer satisfaction levels, low associate turnover, a disciplined cost structure and one team, one goal approach. I'd like to thank all of our 20,000 associates for their commitment and dedication to AutoNation. And with that, I'll turn the call back to Mike Jackson.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Our record third quarter results once again demonstrate our leadership position in the industry and the strength of our diversified and adjusted business model. We are optimistic about the long-term recovery for the U.S. auto market and our
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. Our record third quarter results once again demonstrate our leadership position in the industry and the strength of our diversified and adjusted business model. We are optimistic about the long-term recovery for the U.S. auto market and our ability to capitalize on it. We'll continue to use in planning assumptions for our 2011 full year U.S. industry sales at mid-12 million new vehicle units. And now, I'd like open up the call for questions.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is coming from John Murphy, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is coming from John Murphy, Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: A sort of a longer-term question for you guys. As we look at the first 3 quarters of this year, the SAAR's running at about 12.5 million units, and if we look back at a period of time where you had similar earnings to what you did in the first 3 quarters
componenttext: A sort of a longer-term question for you guys. As we look at the first 3 quarters of this year, the SAAR's running at about 12.5 million units, and if we look back at a period of time where you had similar earnings to what you did in the first 3 quarters this year, it would be the first 3 quarters of 2007 when we saw 16.1 million units. And looking at that, you guys have kind of shot the lights out here on execution and growing your earnings or stabilizing the earnings in a tough time. I'm just curious, as we step forward and the really recovers, do you there's any cost creep or any risk that this great execution kind of slips little bit or are we just looking at this real paradigm shift in your earnings potential here. And as we see the SAAR AR increase really can earn significantly more money than in the past.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd answer it this way. First, we given up above where we think the industry and the market is going and they are. And there, we are convinced that this market is on a journey back to something around 16 million units plus or minus 500,000 either way. And
componenttext: I'd answer it this way. First, we given up above where we think the industry and the market is going and they are. And there, we are convinced that this market is on a journey back to something around 16 million units plus or minus 500,000 either way. And I think there's 3 fundamental drivers to that. There's definite pent-up demand, genuine replacement need. The cars that we are creating everyday in looking at are old and tired, and the customers want to trade them in, with the average age pushing 11 years. At the same time, for the brands we represent, every manufacturers there was a fantastic products with a full spectrum of small cars through pickup trucks. And finally, financing for our customers is very much available and very much at attractive rates. The banks and the finance companies during this disruptive period from '08 till today really took minimal, if any, losses in automotive retail. And consequently, since there's still stress in commercial real estate and the whole mortgage market in small business loans, they are really interested in the automotive space. So those 3 factors of genuine replacement need, exciting new products and very good financing available convinces me that we're on the road back to 16 million. And the only debate is the rate of the recovery. I think then, also speaking of '08, '09 and '10, if you look at AutoNation's performance and everyone's validation of the work that we were doing with our eye on the long term, I mean that was the ultimate test. And if you look at our performance a while for the competition, I think we really distinguished ourselves. Now having said all of that, we don't give forward guidance per se. We say, hey, look at our past performance. Look at where we think the market is going and the rest is really up to you.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, this is Mike Short. Let me just add a thought on the operating leverage because I think that's tangentially related to the question that you asked. And I think what we've tried to communicate in the past is we think right now, our operating costs st
componenttext: John, this is Mike Short. Let me just add a thought on the operating leverage because I think that's tangentially related to the question that you asked. And I think what we've tried to communicate in the past is we think right now, our operating costs structure is about 50% fixed and 50% variable. And with the variable elements largely being compensation and things that are commission and structure based. As time passes, we would expect to see that leverage continued to drop to the bottom line and we're operating at really dramatically improved SG&A as a percentage of growth from where we were a year or 2 ago, but we're still not back from where we've been in the past. We've been down below 70% as in SG&A as a percentage of gross in  the past. And our goal is to get back there and continue to drive that number lower. And we have been investing as Mike mentioned throughout the downturn in some of the very important initiative that we have been including our Shared Service Center, and that's coming along very well. We're almost done with the rollout of that. We've one regional left to go that we should do next year, as well as building new capabilities. For example, when we're starting, we're in very early innings of developing our ability to leverage our capability. And so there's additional opportunity out there for us. But we're working hard on it and I think you have seen it in our results.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Second question, obviously, pricing was strong in the quarter. That was a really good factor for yourselves and the industry. There were some real concerns that is Toyota and Honda restocked, that we're going to see this new round of pricing awards as the
componenttext: Second question, obviously, pricing was strong in the quarter. That was a really good factor for yourselves and the industry. There were some real concerns that is Toyota and Honda restocked, that we're going to see this new round of pricing awards as they try to call back some of their lost market share, which I'm not sure I would really agree with. I just wanted to hear your thoughts on that. Specifically because it doesn't make a lot sense to me given the inventory is tight across the board and probably will still be tight there. It just seems not to be too logical but, there's a real prevailing thought that pricing might erode significantly and may impact your business, as well as the industry at large.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, it's Mike Jackson first. And then I'll have Mike Maroone discuss it in more detail. In principle, I see a much more rational, sustainable industry than what we've had in the past. And I think the manufacturers have really fundamentally changed their
componenttext: John, it's Mike Jackson first. And then I'll have Mike Maroone discuss it in more detail. In principle, I see a much more rational, sustainable industry than what we've had in the past. And I think the manufacturers have really fundamentally changed their outlook. Not to say it won't be competitive, but I really don't see a price war being unleashed as the Japanese availability improves in the marketplace. I think incentives will step up somewhat. But my sense on the domestic is that they know they stabilized their share. They may even have improved their share somewhat, but they have a spike in share due to the lack of availability by the Japanese. And I don't see any steps on their part to do mega-programs like that we had in the summer of '05 of employee pricing in order to try to keep their share at $47.5. So I don't expect that. I expect it would be a normal marketing between here and now and by that I mean aggressive and competitive. But no attempt to say that the domestics have to stay in the high 40s. Having said all of that, I think we have had an extraordinary detour away from normal marketing for 6 months with this unique situation with the Japanese. We learned a lot from it with our pricing tools. Some of that I think is a permanent value to us, but they'll probably some impact on front and gross profit going to the fourth quarter. But I don't see anything dramatic or anything like that.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, to support Mike's view. We're about to roll out version 3 of our pricing tool. And we believe that we've really developed a new capability in this disruption. No, I don't believe we can maintain our Q2 and Q3 margins, but we definitely believe that
componenttext: John, to support Mike's view. We're about to roll out version 3 of our pricing tool. And we believe that we've really developed a new capability in this disruption. No, I don't believe we can maintain our Q2 and Q3 margins, but we definitely believe that there's opportunity over where we've been in the past. We've improved margins both on the Domestic side and the Premium Luxury side and the Import side. So we're optimistic. We're updating our pricing weekly now. Our old organization is focused on it. We have just got done doing our quarterly operating reviews at everybody is confident that we are headed off to a new capability and we could put it to good use going forward. I do want to point out as I did in my script though, that in Q4, we've got back on that includes about $250 a cars that was a onetime performance-based incentive last year.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on the share repurchase program or the new that's been in place and what has been going on for years, from 2003 to where we are right now, you've cut your share count in half. If you were to keep that rate up, you guys would have boug
componenttext: And then just lastly on the share repurchase program or the new that's been in place and what has been going on for years, from 2003 to where we are right now, you've cut your share count in half. If you were to keep that rate up, you guys would have bought back all of your shares in the next 8 years if you've keep at that absolute rate. I'm just curious as to all of us in the investment community thinking about where your share count ultimately will go and really what the end goal here is. It almost seems like it's a slow-motion or maybe not even such a slow-motion privatization of the company. I'm just curious, how far do the share buybacks go. Obviously, it makes a lot of sense from a capital structure standpoint. But just curious how far you go with this?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well I think share buyback has been very beneficial for our shareholders of the years. And I think it's actually on my watch more than half. I think when I arrived, it was something like 530 million shares outstanding. And today we're at 140 million share
componenttext: Well I think share buyback has been very beneficial for our shareholders of the years. And I think it's actually on my watch more than half. I think when I arrived, it was something like 530 million shares outstanding. And today we're at 140 million shares outstanding. And if you look at how we bought in this last quarter again, we did it opportunistically. There's a lot of volatility in the equity market that applies to us also. The large price swings and within the quarter and we saw moments where we could step in and take advantage of it. Whether we have those types of opportunities in the future, no one knows. We don't know. So again, we have the same capital allocation approach that we've had since I've been here. And there is no end game specific in mind. We decided on a quarter-by-quarter basis looking at the opportunities on acquisitions. And we have share repurchase opportunities and we discuss the full range of capital allocation possibilities that are there. And we make those decisions on a quarterly basis.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Himanshu Patel of JP Morgan Chase.
componenttext: The next question is coming from Himanshu Patel of JP Morgan Chase.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Amy in for Himanshu Patel. I just have a few questions. And I wanted to touch base a little bit on the retail used vehicle margin. I think last quarter, you guys had suggested that it would be pricing would be more of an issue, but that the margin
componenttext: This is Amy in for Himanshu Patel. I just have a few questions. And I wanted to touch base a little bit on the retail used vehicle margin. I think last quarter, you guys had suggested that it would be pricing would be more of an issue, but that the margin would still be relatively okay. I mean I heard what you just said to John, but do you mind just kind of drilling down a little bit deeper on what was the change and what was expected versus what actually occurred?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Mike Maroone. A couple of things. One is we have continued to grow the VVO, or Value Vehicle Outlet business, which are lower-priced cars that have lower margins. We retailed 4,300 of those in the quarter at lower margins, but we believe we're expand
componenttext:
It's Mike Maroone. A couple of things. One is we have continued to grow the VVO, or Value Vehicle Outlet business, which are lower-priced cars that have lower margins. We retailed 4,300 of those in the quarter at lower margins, but we believe we're expanding our customer base in doing so. So that was one. Our secondly is as the inventory disruption occurred, we got very aggressive buying Hondas, Toyotas and other import products. And frankly, the market shifted slightly as they began to resume production. That production resumption was a little bit ahead of schedule. And so what we did is we liquidated some of that inventory and took small wholesale losses, but also took lower retail grocers. So that it was a little bit of an unusual situation, but we felt that we wanted to get right sized so that we could compete in both the new and used vehicle business.
I think the third factor is that the Premium Luxury segment had far less return, and those were generally high margin business that we did not, we were not able to take advantage of them that the quarter. So all in all our used car business was up slightly. We did give up a little bit of gross, but we feel very good about our position today, and our inventories are clean and in good shape. And we're looking forward to performing in the quarter.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and can you just clarify how many of the Japanese, I think you said 44 total days of use or 43, do you have a breakout of like the different J3 versus Domestic and Premium?
componenttext: Okay, and can you just clarify how many of the Japanese, I think you said 44 total days of use or 43, do you have a breakout of like the different J3 versus Domestic and Premium?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Generally, I don't have it at the tip of my fingers. But it generally doesn't change much. We try and run normally in a 35 to 38 days supply. And I think you'll see our inventories in that range in the fourth quarter. But it doesn't vary greatly. Where we
componenttext: Generally, I don't have it at the tip of my fingers. But it generally doesn't change much. We try and run normally in a 35 to 38 days supply. And I think you'll see our inventories in that range in the fourth quarter. But it doesn't vary greatly. Where we did have exposure in our Import, we did bring that down at the end of the quarter. And again, as I said, we're in good shape today. So that doesn't vary much by segment.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, in the last question that I have is on your comments about interest and acquisitions. Are you guys looking to fill in like brands or brands or footprint or can you give a little bit color on what you're looking for. And what is the size, like what y
componenttext: Okay, in the last question that I have is on your comments about interest and acquisitions. Are you guys looking to fill in like brands or brands or footprint or can you give a little bit color on what you're looking for. And what is the size, like what you see in terms of size potential that you could possibly have appetite for.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Jackson. We've had basically the same diversified strategy since I have been here. But when it comes acquisitions, the principle is density and all the major brands in the market. So we are very much focused on our existing footprint, not goi
componenttext: This is Mike Jackson. We've had basically the same diversified strategy since I have been here. But when it comes acquisitions, the principle is density and all the major brands in the market. So we are very much focused on our existing footprint, not going to additional markets. And then we're targeted, and ultimately, ideally someday, we'd like to have all the major brands within the market that we're in. We think there's a lot of power in that idea, in that concept, whether we'll be able to get there or not is another story entirely, but that we are the focus of our acquisition team is and that is where we'd ultimately like to be.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: We have an excellent shipment schedule from the Japanese for the fourth quarter, something over 30,000 units for us without some sort of perspective I would say normally, we would like to have gotten 27,000. We got under 20,000 in the third quarter and ev
componenttext: We have an excellent shipment schedule from the Japanese for the fourth quarter, something over 30,000 units for us without some sort of perspective I would say normally, we would like to have gotten 27,000. We got under 20,000 in the third quarter and even less than that in the second quarter. So clearly, there are approaching 100% if not 110%, 115% on production side. You have to make an assumption on what the selling rate of that is going to be. We think it's going to be fairly high. Meaning, to get back to inventory level that 45 to 60 days that would make sense, you're probably in the first quarter of next year, if not, even into the second quarter, depending how the selling rate goes. But -- so the point is, we'll have good shipment. We'll have good fresh inventory that's in line with what customers want. But really restock is going to take some time of shipments above 100% of market demand.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: In that type of environment, Mike, would you think of the out of the J3 would probably be relatively restrained and you'd be able to hang on to some of those gross profit to side?
componenttext: In that type of environment, Mike, would you think of the out of the J3 would probably be relatively restrained and you'd be able to hang on to some of those gross profit to side?

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: I agree with that, Rick. I think there will be some increase in the incentives. Japanese clearly have to stabilize, if not, recover some share. But I don't think a price war being unleashed that is going to be ruining for manufacturers and retailers as fa
componenttext: I agree with that, Rick. I think there will be some increase in the incentives. Japanese clearly have to stabilize, if not, recover some share. But I don't think a price war being unleashed that is going to be ruining for manufacturers and retailers as far as they're margins are getting I think the whole industry is much more rational, much more long-term view, and that's how I expect it to unfold. So it won't be the extreme shortages that we've had for the past 6 months. But there's still going to be an imbalance in the demand and supply. I think there'll be some moderation in growth is but it will not be dramatic.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mike, you have been very accurate with your SAAR forecast as long as I followed the company. Any initial  thoughts on 2012, flat SAAR for 2012.
componenttext: Mike, you have been very accurate with your SAAR forecast as long as I followed the company. Any initial  thoughts on 2012, flat SAAR for 2012.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: You won't hear the word flat coming out of my mouth. So I don't think I disagree with that point of view Again, going back to the 3 fundamental drivers, genuine replacement need, exciting new products, really wonderful financing available. So everything t
componenttext: You won't hear the word flat coming out of my mouth. So I don't think I disagree with that point of view Again, going back to the 3 fundamental drivers, genuine replacement need, exciting new products, really wonderful financing available. So everything that we look at as says sales will be higher next year than they were this year. And I really want to see the inflection rate and the closing selling rate of December to put a number out and this is where we think 2012's going to come out. But I fully expect it will be a number higher than the final number of 2011. It will not be flat. It will be up. The only question is how much up.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from Simeon Gutman with Credit Suisse.

headline: AutoNation Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2011

componenttext: It's Mike Maroone. The one last day adds about 1%. So on a customer pay gross, we go from 2% to 3% just as an example. So it does impact the calculation. In terms of where that business is going, we think there'll be pressures on the units and operations for another year. So we really focused on the customer pay side where we're being very aggressive in our customer offerings and are really glad to be growing that business 5 consecutive quarters on a year-over-year basis with our initiatives.

componenttextpreview: So patrick, within those Shared Service Center and there's a base level and that's accounts payable, receivable reconciliations, and as Mike mentioned, we rolled out now. And for over a year, we've had everybody in that configuration. The real -- the next
componenttext: So patrick, within those Shared Service Center and there's a base level and that's accounts payable, receivable reconciliations, and as Mike mentioned, we rolled out now. And for over a year, we've had everybody in that configuration. The real -- the next level which we call extended has much more beneficial effect in terms of the cost structure. And that's where we actually shift the actual car transactions electronically to our Shared Service Center and they're all processed directly from the Shared Service Center. Just to give you an anecdotal example of that, in all of our stores today that are not in the extended Shared Service Center model, we have 1, maybe 2 people responsible for dealing building the car deals. For the 3 regions, 75% of the company that we have in the Shared Service Center in extended right now able to do all of that billing with 8 people. So it gives you a sense of the magnitude of the efficiencies that we can generate while we're so on the Shared Service Center model here and automation. And it's running very well in the 3 regions where we have it operating right now. So region is not the only reason to expend Shared Service Center completed in the central region right now in Florida will go next year. So I think that's the key behind it. On the purchasing side, we do have a sourcing group here within the company. They're doing a great job. We are thinking about how that we have demonstrated capabilities, expanding their scope to other spend areas. I want to be clear though, we're not talking about the purchasing new vehicles from manufacturers at different prices. This is primarily an idea items, essentially aftermarket parts purchases and things like that. It's less about the buying of vehicles. With respect to our used vehicle business, we do have people who have specific expertise and buying used vehicles on behalf of our stores. But that's different than the core purchasing areas in SG&A and parts and service that I'm talking about.
